title: Getting Started with Was2CoDE
text: Was2CoDE package provides tool analyzing gene expression data individual-level using IDEAS mehtod decomposed components Wasserstein-2 distance. vignette demonstrates use package functions analyze synthetic gene expression data.

title: Getting Started with Was2CoDE
text: First, ensure installed Was2CoDE package GitHub:
code: # Don't run these during build/check install.packages("devtools") install.packages("data.table") install.packages("doRNG")  # Install Was2CoDE from GitHub (example only) devtools::install_github("TatiZhang/Was2CoDE")

title: Getting Started with Was2CoDE
code: # Load the packages library(Was2CoDE) library(data.table) library(doRNG) ## Loading required package: foreach ## Loading required package: rngtools

title: Getting Started with Was2CoDE
code: set.seed(0)  # Number of genes and cells n_genes <- 10 n_cells <- 20  # Generate synthetic gene expression data count_input <- matrix(rnorm(n_genes * n_cells, mean = 5, sd = 2), nrow = n_genes, ncol = n_cells) rownames(count_input) <- paste0("gene", 1:n_genes) colnames(count_input) <- paste0("cell", 1:n_cells)  # Generate metadata for cells meta_cell <- data.frame(   cell_id = colnames(count_input),   individual = rep(paste0("donor", 1:5), each = n_cells / 5),   some_variable = rnorm(n_cells)  # Add a placeholder variable for var_per_cell )  # Generate metadata for individuals meta_ind <- data.frame(   individual = unique(meta_cell$individual),   var2test = rnorm(5) )  var_per_cell <- "some_variable" var2test <- "var2test"

title: Getting Started with Was2CoDE
code: # Compute distance metrics # result <- Was2CoDE::was2code_dist(count_input, meta_cell, meta_ind, var_per_cell, var2test) #  # # Print the result # print(result)

text: Tati Zhang. Author, maintainer.

what: Statistical tool using Was2CoDE method and Was-2 decomposition
title: Statistical tool using Was2CoDE method and Was-2 decomposition
text: URL GitHub (.e., source code) : https://github.com/TatiZhang/IdeasCustom URL Pkgdown webpage : https://tatizhang.github.io/IdeasCustom/index.html

title: Statistical tool using Was2CoDE method and Was-2 decomposition
text: IdeasCustom package provides tool analyzing gene expression data individual-level using IDEAS mehtod decomposed components Wasserstein-2 distance. includes functions arrange gene expression data donors, initialize distance array lists, compute divergence metrics using Wasserstein distance, . package designed facilitate exploration analysis complex gene expression datasets.

title: Statistical tool using Was2CoDE method and Was-2 decomposition
text: can install IdeasCustom package GitHub using following commands:
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install IdeasCustom from GitHub devtools::install_github("TatiZhang/IdeasCustom")

title: Statistical tool using Was2CoDE method and Was-2 decomposition
Arrange Genes by Donors — arrange_genes_by_donors
text: function arranges gene expression data donors, reformatting count matrix genes donors. gene count matrix, iterates individual metadata extracts corresponding expression data, organizing donors.

title: Arrange Genes by Donors — arrange_genes_by_donors
code: arrange_genes_by_donors(count_matrix, meta_ind, meta_cell)

title: Arrange Genes by Donors — arrange_genes_by_donors
text: count_matrix matrix gene expression data (genes rows, cells columns) meta_ind data frame individual/donor metadata meta_cell data frame cell metadata

title: Arrange Genes by Donors — arrange_genes_by_donors
text: dat_res, list (genes) lists (donors)

title: define divergence() using wasserstein1d() — divergence
text: define divergence() using wasserstein1d()

title: define divergence() using wasserstein1d() — divergence
code: divergence(a, b, p = 2, verbose = 0)

title: define divergence() using wasserstein1d() — divergence
text: Numeric (gene expressions) vector. b Numeric (gene expressions) vector. p Integer, power parameter Wasserstein distance.

title: define divergence() using wasserstein1d() — divergence
text: numeric vector containing four divergence metrics: distance, location difference, size difference, shape difference.

what: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
title: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
text: internal function constructs 3D array list distance matrices, matrix corresponds specific gene contains pairwise distances donors.

title: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
code: .form_dist_array(dist_list)

title: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
text: dist_array_list named list distance matrices. element list corresponds gene contains 3D array third dimension includes "was2" distance.

title: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
text: 3D array dimensions (n_genes, n_donors, n_donors), n_genes number genes n_donors number donors. array indexed gene contains "was2" distances donors.

title: Form a 3D Distance Array from a List of Distance Matrices — .form_dist_array
code: # Example usage (assuming `dist_list` is a valid input) dist_array <- .form_dist_array(dist_list) #> Error in .form_dist_array(dist_list): could not find function ".form_dist_array"

text: https://academic.oup.com/gigascience/article/8/9/giz106/5570567

title: Lin et al. housekeeping genes — housekeeping_lin_df
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # How the data was loaded df <- openxlsx::read.xlsx("giz106_supplemental_table.xlsx", sheet = "human development") colnames(df)[1] <- "Gene" df$Housekeeping <- (df$Stability.index > 0.8) df <- df[,c("Gene", "Stability.index", "Housekeeping")] housekeeping_lin_df <- df usethis::use_data(housekeeping_lin_df)  # To load housekeeping_lin <- housekeeping_lin_df$Gene[housekeeping_lin_df$Housekeeping] } # }

title: Sun et al. microglia AD genes — microglia_prater_df

title: Sun et al. microglia AD genes — microglia_prater_df
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # How the data was loaded df <- openxlsx::read.xlsx("43587_2023_424_MOESM3_ESM.xlsx", sheet = "AD_vs_Ctrl_DEGs", startRow = 3) microglia_prater_df <- df enriched_genes <- unique(microglia_prater_df$Gene[microglia_prater_df$padj <= 0.05]) microglia_prater_df$DEG <- (microglia_prater_df$Gene %in% enriched_genes) usethis::use_data(microglia_prater_df)  # To load microglia_prater <- unique(microglia_prater_df$Gene[microglia_prater_df$DEG]) } # }

title: Sun et al. microglia AD genes — microglia_sun_df
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # How the data was loaded df <- openxlsx::read.xlsx("1-s2.0-S0092867423009716-mmc1.xlsx", sheet = "Page 10.DEGs_AD") colnames(df)[1] <- "Gene" microglia_sun_df <- df table_vec <- table(microglia_sun_df$Gene) enriched_genes <- unique(names(table_vec)[table_vec >= 5]) microglia_sun_df$DEG <- (microglia_sun_df$Gene %in% enriched_genes) usethis::use_data(microglia_sun_df)  # To load microglia_sun <- unique(microglia_sun_df$Gene[microglia_sun_df$DEG]) } # }

what: Plot Signed Log P-values for Two Methods/Datasets — plot_signed_logpval
title: Plot Signed Log P-values for Two Methods/Datasets — plot_signed_logpval
text: Creates scatter plot comparing signed log p-values two differential expression methods/datasets, optional highlighting specific genes pathways. signed log p-value calculated sign(logFC) * -log10(p-value), allows visualization significance direction change.

title: Plot Signed Log P-values for Two Methods/Datasets — plot_signed_logpval
code: plot_signed_logpval(   df,   method1,   method2,   bool_capped = TRUE,   bool_multtestadjust = TRUE,   highlight_features = NULL )

title: Plot Signed Log P-values for Two Methods/Datasets — plot_signed_logpval
text: df data frame containing gene names results two methods. Must contain columns: Feature, method1_logFC, method1_pval, method2_logFC, method2_pval method1 method2 replaced actual method names. method1 Character string specifying name first method. Used construct column names (e.g., "DESeq2" looks "DESeq2_logFC" "DESeq2_pval"). method2 Character string specifying name second method. Used construct column names (e.g., "edgeR" looks "edgeR_logFC" "edgeR_pval"). bool_capped Logical indicating whether cap extreme values. Currently unused values automatically capped 97.5% quantile visualization. bool_multtestadjust Logical indicating whether draw dotted lines nominal multiple-test-corrected pvalues (default). highlight_features Character vector gene names highlight red. NULL (default), genes significant methods (FDR < 0.05) highlighted.

title: Plot Signed Log P-values for Two Methods/Datasets — plot_signed_logpval
text: ggplot2 object showing comparison plot : Purple shaded regions indicating significance methods Dashed lines showing FDR cutoffs Coral line showing first principal component Red points labels highlighted genes Correlation Fisher test results title

title: Generate Result Array List — result_array_list

what: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Between Individuals — was2code_dist
title: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Between Individuals — was2code_dist
text: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Individuals

title: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Between Individuals — was2code_dist
code: was2code_dist(   count_input,   meta_cell,   meta_ind,   var_per_cell,   var2test,   ncores = 2,   k = NULL,   verbose = 0 )

title: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Between Individuals — was2code_dist
text: count_input count matrix (genes x cells) meta_cell Cell-level metadata including 'individual' 'cell_id' meta_ind Individual-level metadata including 'individual' test variable var_per_cell Variable normalize per cell (e.g., "nCount_RNA") var2test Binary variable test individual level ncores Number cores use parallelization k Number opposite-group individuals compare person (default = NULL )

title: Compute Wasserstein-2 Distance Between Individuals — was2code_dist
text: list 3D distance arrays (one per gene)

what: Compute standardized logFC-style effect sizes from Was2CoDE output — was2code_lfc

text: Compute standardized logFC-style effect sizes Was2CoDE output

code: was2code_lfc(dist_list, case_idx, control_idx)

title: Compute standardized logFC-style effect sizes from Was2CoDE output — was2code_lfc
text: dist_list list distance arrays (was2code_dist) case_idx Integer vector row indices corresponding cases control_idx Integer vector row indices corresponding controls

title: Compute standardized logFC-style effect sizes from Was2CoDE output — was2code_lfc
text: matrix genes rows distance components columns: columns = c("was2", "location", "size", "shape")
